content.body: i think i've gotten by my Shared Worker impass, thanks to zcorpan

seems like the only intuitive way to implement "mouse over" equivalent on touchscreen devices is to also have a proximity sensor on the device that can detect when you are actually hovering over something with your finger

there is a big irony in the fact that the prevalent GUI conventions are modeled on physical desktop conventions that can't currently be implemented practically on devices that provide a greater degree of real physical interaction with the UI (through the touchscreen) rather than through the abstraction of a separate pointing device
, with those words of wisdom, finishes off his second breakfast beer, while trying to avoid spilling it on his laptop keyboard
breakfast?
looks at watch
late breakfast methinks
indeed
wirepair: actually, late lunch
*nod* <-- in japan as well
I didn't have time for my breakfast beers today, so I'm playing catch-up
heh
wirepair: where in Japan?
oota-ku
ah cool
yourself?
i'm normally in Shinjuku or nearby, or at the W3C office at Keio U. near Fujisawa, or out and about elsewhere
at the moment I'm actually in Mitaka
at an NTT tech expo that's going on today
ah cool, didn't realize w3c had an office here heh
yeah, smallish office
in terms of people, currently
i used to be at symc, did some browser security assessments and been hooked on browsers ever since, so decided to hang out here see what cooky stuff you guys are cooking up ;>
er symc = symantec
excellent
I would guess you might have some good insight into client-side security issues
which the community could definitely use more of
yeah i've been passively reading ;>
mainly seeing in fighting though ;>
wirepair: you may want to read up on iframe/@srcdoc and get involved in recent discussion of that
got a link for that?
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/text-level-semantics.html#attr-iframe-srcdoc
thanks
and see related discussion on that whatwg mailing list
will try to get a link for that too
appreciate it
I don't know if you aware already but another thing that's been in the works for some time now is a mechanism for enabling cross-origin (cross-site) XHR (and other forms of cross-origin requests)
that is definitely worth taking a loot at too
Cross Origin Resource Sharing
yeah, i've read a little about it
couldn't see anything immediately wrong with the preflights, but i think it may boil down to browser implementation
wirepair: you've read up on the alternative Uniform Messaging proposal as well?
hmm, no i have not i've honestly been busy building my testing framework heh
wirepair: about recent iframe discussions, http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2009-December/thread.html#24487 is a good place to start if/when you have time
yeah i should be testing this web app ehe, i'll check it after work
はい
blarg, stupid utf-7 term

MikeSmith: oops
no biggie
the dev.w3.org version is linked to in plenty of other messages, so I'm sure people can put 2 and 2 together

http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Feb/0160.html and http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Feb/0171.html
I guess I should try to see if I can get someone to respond to those points
Hey all, how's everyone tonight (or whatever time it is where you exist) ?
MikeSmith: does the spec currently require that?
othermaciej: I was thinking maybe the change proposal was advocating for having it be a warning, but maybe in fact it doesn't and that suggestion only came up on the e-mail thread
goes to looks now
my brain hurts from sending all that email
and I still need to write an agenda
I need to write an agenda for the accessibility TF call for this week too
which is less work
but I believe we will have two actual proposals from the TF to move forward to the wider group of the a11y TF telcon this week
the canvas adom proposal and the summary proposal
*move forward to the wider group for further discussion
which reminds me also that I wanted to check in with Silvia
nessy: you around and have time to chat a bit about status on the media proposals?
OK, I see that Richard's change proposal for issue 88 in fact says nothing about warning on absence of lang
so nm
http://dvcs.w3.org/hg
"range of expectation" is pretty narrow as far as desktop browsers go...
ok, why is it that the various Calls for Whatever I posted today drew so many random follow-up comments?
most of the things of this type that the Chairs post get no responses at all
hsivonen: does .@ mean something special in twitter-ese (as opposed to just @)
"So if someone really wanted to propose allowing the rel attribute on elements, that would be in scope (though in my opinion, it would be a silly idea)." - RDFa already makes that allowed
(if I'm not misreading the DTD)
othermaciej: It means I wanted to broadcast those tweets to all my followers--not just those who also follow masinter
I did not know twitter made such a distinction
has learned something
Is it just me or does "The requirement is from TimBL's original axioms." come close to the axiomatic proof?
ok, someone tell me that I shouldn't reply to Roy's latest email
because, if we're gonna drop ping anyway, there is no point debating it
I don't really understand why anyone would like the idea of simply removing the W3C logo from the feature, when it's equally likely to be implemented if it's in a WHATWG spec
Isn't the idea meant to be to improve the feature?
Not if you think it's broken by design, I suppose

If you think that, I still don't see why you'd happy to just have it move to a different spec where it'll get implemented just the same and you won't have any chance to provide feedback to make it slightly less broken
Philip`: You make a clear statement that you're against it, and wash your hands of the consequences
Philip`: having it only in the WHATWG spec takes it away from the W3C PP, which might have an impact on the willingness of some vendors to implement
"I look forward to the more exciting XHTML2 phase of our Working Group" -- hehe
Oh wow
Valve is beta testing webkit for their Steam service
http://store.steampowered.com/uiupdate/
annevk: source?

notes that the name "HTML5 (including next generation additions still in development)" came after a long discussion about how people would get confused if they were pointed to something that people normally call "HTML5" and the document did not call itself HTML5
hsivonen, http-state mailing list, othermaciej being sarcastic about the suggestion that we should replace cookies
annevk: after he called it "phase 2" I could barely resist

asmodai: It's interesting since they've used IE for years, and have presumably put a lot of effort into understanding it, and only care about Windows support, and still WebKit offers sufficient technical benefits to switch
Philip`: I just updated it, man, does it look slick
("we swapped out the Internet Explorer rendering engine with WebKit, which gives us a bunch of size, stability and performance benefits")
yeah, it starts up noticeably faster too
Even without any direct benefits, being able to support a single version of webkit seems better than 3-4 different IE engines
Jesus, I wonder how long they worked on this
If I now click my games it will present me with so much more information
Surely you only need to support one IE engine, and put the others in compatibility mode
annevk: thanks
Google FAIL: http://www.google.fi/search?q=http-state+archive
http-state worked :)
googling for 'ietf mailing list' and navigating worked, too
yes I was snarky to Adam: http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/http-state/current/msg00589.html
I hope he forgives me
i really, really, really wish i could put unique data into the method of the websocket handshake
before the resource
that would make it _so_ much harder to screw up the server-side implementation of this
definitely seems like it would reduce the attack surface
something like "WS012 /resource/ HTTP/1.1"
where the three digits have to be converted to a number by parsing them as a decimal
Hixie: so what is preventing you from doing that?

annevk: in all sincerity, I am pretty dubious of the prospects for or even usefulness of an incompatible replacement for cookies, but it's probably not *quite* as silly as an incompatible replacement for HTML
MikeSmith: seems like it would be a pain for HTTP servers to dispatch on, if they dispatch based on method

and then some other number has to be divided by that number, so even if the implementor really screws it up, the number they get will be zero, and the division will crash the server rather than let it be attacked
MikeSmith: also, I am sure it would make the HTTP gods furious with hot anger
MikeSmith: the wg members are up in arms enough as it is, and i'm using existing methods
othermaciej, I'm skeptical as well
othermaciej, though maybe if HTTP authentication is made useful enough... but then I'm not sure if that would be sufficient
annevk: I guess I haven't seen Adam's use cases that would justify a replacement for cookies as the solution
annevk: being able to tie form-based login to HTTP auth would remove a decent fraction of the true need for cookies, but the way to achieve that is not through a protcol spec
annevk: but on the other hand, most of the cookies currently in my cookie store are not login cookies
i love that if i telnet to port 80 of hixie.ch and then send "GET / HTTP/1.1" (with no Host:) I get a 400, but if I send "GET / WEBSOCKET" I get a 200 OK with an error message
othermaciej, yeah, but those might be replaced I suppose with localStorage and XHR... though maybe not
annevk: those aren't protocol specs either...
true, not sure how much protocol changes would be needed
maybe a little, to support logout
hmm... if I include a Host:, they both work
i wonder whether we can just send WebSocket instead of HTTP/1.1
Hixie, maybe with the second one it assumes HTTP/0.9?
annevk: I guess I should hold my fire until Adam presents the use cases and or design for Phase 2
annevk: maybe...
annevk: the other thing Phase 2 makes me think of is... underpants gnomes
eh?
underpants gnomes?
ah, south park
btw, news flash: sitting in a chair all day in front of a computer can make you fat and unhealthy: http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/02/23/stand-up-while-you-read-this/
it appears that some scientists have been looking into this
this comes to mind: http://or.ly/
MikeSmith: That's misrepresenting the article gravely
"In other words, irrespective of whether you exercise vigorously, sitting for long periods is bad for you."
gravely indeed
my apologies
annevk: I assume the site shows the orly owl, but I don't know because it's hostile to my Referer settings
types up a retraction
Dashiva: That sentence seems to be misrepresenting the rest of the article
dang I sit for long periods
me too
so I'm switching to lying down
reconsiders the idea of a standing height workstation
sideways, Roman-feast style
othermaciej: Even better, walkstations
Threadmill + workstation
MikeSmith: I'm not sure the Roman feast helps with weight issues
-h I guess
Dashiva: That's what the article suggests
Presumably it would be treadmill + workstation + need to go fast enough or the computer will die
the best solution to the weight issues is probably to combine the sitting with a lot of meth smoking
what exactly is the "bad"?
jgraham: Can't go that fast, or you get exhausted before the end of the day
Right but presumably the benefits are lost somewhat if you just stand there
Even standing still is a great improvement over sitting
I like how the references section is about as long as the main article
Hixie: Obesity, diabetes, heart disease, cancer, and death, which all sound quite bad to me
Dashiva: her articles are almost always like that
Philip`: good to know
A ray of hope in an otherwise desolate journalistic landscape
Sitting down can kill puppies too
Dashiva: she's actually more of genuine scientist that an journalist.. some of her prose is just awful
but her stuff is always worth reading
Hixie: btw, need I ask, but are you perhaps planning to attend the hybi f2f in Anaheim on March 24?
not in person
ok
probably on irc and listening, though if it doesn't seem productive i'll drop off
hmm, that really makes me think.. there's no fee for calling in to the meeting, right?
nope
if you were to actually attend in person, I think you'd need to pay 200 USD to do it
you don't call in actually
ah yeah
right
you get a live audio feed and there's an IM bachchannel
MikeSmith: !
spec experts: is it valid to use percent-encoding even when it isn't necessary? e.g. to encoding a as %61
in URIs that is
Hixie: that is what I had to pay to attend Hiroshima for 1 day
foolip, yup
ok
yeah, and USD 600 for a week or so
wow, that's worse than the w3c's tpac $50/day extortion
man i hate f2fs
MikeSmith: dang, that's expensive
I was thinking about going or sending a minion but I'm not sure I could justify that cost on top of travel and hotel
for the IRC part in IETF meetings, you are allowed to get in the speaker queue and type questions and the chairs read them out, right?
othermaciej: it may be there is some other way to attend without paying that much but if so, I don't know about it and it was not offered to me as an option
had to pay €565 for 5 days at a networking conference
MikeSmith, yeah, not necessarily by the chairs though
(Well, my university had to pay)
concluded that it wasn't worth it
MikeSmith: there's three sessions of interest in the whole f2f, each on a different day, and nothing I would be remotely interested in for the rest of the day
Philip`: not enough massages and mint juleps included in the deal?
wait, I forgot about IR
IRI
wonders if that is a fourth day
othermaciej: luckily, last time time IRI and hybi meetings were on the same day
I don't know about this year
MikeSmith: None at all
Philip`: then you definitely got gipped
(The hotel was another €500)
hybi, iribis, httpbis, http-state would be the sessions I might be interested in
ah yeah, http-state
othermaciej, same here, but I don't think I'll be going
I guess abarth will be that one at least
there was no http WG f2f in Hiroshima last time

Though I'm considered for IRI co-chair apparently there are other candidates as well so it doesn't really seem worth my time to fly over there. On top of that there's something fun going in the Netherlands at the same time :)
I wonder if it's permitted to allow people to voip/Skype others in so they can actually ask and answer questions verbally instead of just by IRC
MikeSmith: my understanding is taht it is
or at least, that option was offered to me for anaheim
OK
frankly though the idea of _charging_ people to participate in what should be completely open standards development is just insane to me
i hated when w3c did it, and i hate it when ietf does it
especially given how often ietf does it
so httpbis is Monday, httpstate is Tuesday, hybi is Wednesday, and iri is Friday
I think part of the IETF reason is that they othwerwise charge no membership fees
Hixie: I wish the W3C could figure out sponsorship instead of charing fees to individuals
(if google hadn't paid for a bunch of people to go to the htmlwg meeting, i probably wouldn't have gone)
for TPAC
i'm really not at all convinced f2fs are that good
like have some corps pay big bucks to have their logos on a page in the conference program
othermaciej: well, me too
people keep saying they're useful because of the social aspects
but that hasn't helped the htmlwg much as far as i can tell
mostly because most people can't go anyway
so why bother
TC-39 meeting is Wednesday and Thursday, the same week as the IETF meeting, so I'm missing at least hybi
which is too bad because that's the one where I most expect to be able to have a useful impact
#whatwg is useful because of the social aspects
but it hasn't helped the htmlwg much as far as i can tell
we started an irc channel quite a long time into the whatwg being quite productive
iirc
so i don't think irc really helped in that respect
it's fun and helpful, but it's not necessary, imho
f2fs aren't even fun and helpful
they're miserable and generally a waste of time, imho
2010 W3C AC meeting is 22nd and 23rd March in Cambridge, btw. so anybody attending that won't be able to attend the first two days of the IETF meetings
I feel like I get some value out of f2fs but I have never tried to quantify
<Dracula> What is a f2f?
face-to-face
It was a joke, pay it no heed :)

othermaciej: i used to think so, then i tried to measure the net impact on the specs i was working on, and i determined that it didn't unblock any blocked issues, and yet basically inserted a 10-day delay (assuming a 3-day meeting with 2 travel days)
Dashiva: d'oh
as I think hsivonen pointed out, the worst part by far of f2f meetings is the travel part
especially if you happen to live in a part of the world far away from where most of the f2f meetings take place
Hixie: the opportunity cost is my biggest worry

the main value I feel I have experienced is in conveying information about complex technical issues that seemed impossible to transfer in email, and opportunistically learning interesting facts from people I run into
I don't understand larry's latest blog post. What are these superfluous MUSTs he's concerned about?
Dashiva: You mean all the anti-competitive ones?
"HTML5 also suffers from problems in Firefox 2 and Camino 1 because these two browsers use the Gecko rendering engine." - http://www.whatcreative.co.uk/blog/?p=410
The only one I can think of is that .width and .height aren't allowed to disappear for no reason
And that just shows how little he cares about usable APIs
where are .width and .height not allowed?
or were there too many negatives in that sentence
The values must remain available once they become available
What happens to .width/.height in e.g. Opera when you disable images after loading a page?
assumes they return 0 but hasn't tested
The images remain with the same size, they just don't render
The layout is fully preserved
Hum
Maybe that's styling interfering, though. Let's check otherwise.
Dashiva: i get layout changes when i turn off images
Dashiva: at least when there's alt text
Yeah, there was a fixed image size where I was checking.
Without styles, it resizes to fit the alt tex, and the dimensions match that
sounds like some kind of bug
annevk: was there any kind of resolution at all on the "Backward-compatibility of text/html media type" thread on the TAG mailing list a few weeks back?
I think you posted a few messages about that
I did and I don't think there was
finds http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2010Feb/thread.html#msg23
You sometimes go in a discussion with the TAG but then it takes ages for them to reply
I think they may be waiting on some kind of update from the HTML WG
I guess in the end we just disagreed
I'm trying to find what HTML WG bugzilla bug is associated with that, if any
i randomly picked this mail from that thread:
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2010Feb/0027.html
which asks:
1.  Is there an intention to have at least the vast majority of the older
content work and be considered conforming?
wonders if Noah realises that the vast majority of the older content _isn't_ considered conforming even under the old rules
I guess I first probably should try to figure out exactly what the TAG seems to be asking for around this
wonders if Noah realizes that "work" and "be considered conforming" are independent axes?
OK
I think I understand what the question/request is
Not really independent, but not parallel either
I think it's about whether the spec says that documents with an HTML 2, 3.2, 4 or XHTML 1 doctype are considered to be text/html documents or not
doesn't think that parallel is quite the right word
in the case of HTML 4.01, there are documents that "work" but are not conforming, and documents which do not work, but are conforming
http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/group/track/actions/364 is public right?
maybe not an orthonormal basis, but definitely not identical
MikeSmith: is there any way for me to tell, given that I have Member access?
I guess I could figure out how to delete my http password
aren't all the tracker instances world-readable?
othermaciej: using curl or wget or whatever, I guess
it curls
OK, so I see there that action is a "give somebody else an action" action
and the somebody else in this case is me
yes
or PLH
and the action we are expected to do is to write a change proposal
x3d profiles, hmm
on something you may or may not believe in
yeah
I would much prefer for Change Proposals to be written by actual advocates for the change in question
(no need to be a WG member; DanC is signed up for one already)
that'd certainly seem to be the best way to get them written, if they are to be written well
this is otherwise like some kind of telephone-game thing
however that issue is also one we decided we do not need to address before LC
oh
I sorta remember that now, yeah
OK, so I guess I can respond to say that
which is why it is in "HTML5 Spec - PR Blockers" instead of "HTML5 spec"
which I guess means my open issue count is off by one
I wish I could look at the issues for a specific product
you can, can't you?
how?
http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/products/8
how that's cool
reads the recent public-html thread related to this
it even consolidates open and raised
this is now my favorite page on the tracker: http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/products/1
maybe the title should be "HTML5 (*plus* next-gen additions additions still in development)"
hmm appending ,access does not work on dynamic URIs
annevk: right, unfortunately
zcorpan: that would make more sense
Hixie: ^
othermaciej: can you give me some guidance from your chairs perspective about what update I should give to the TAG about this?
annevk: cool. I was unaware of ,access
MikeSmith: I dunno
MikeSmith: have they made a request of you yet?
othermaciej: just, "The group is planning resolve the text/html media-type registration issue after LC"
hmm, I don't think that will fly
othermaciej: DanC pinged me about it
hot potato
MikeSmith: we previously decided that ISSUE-53 doesn't need to be addressed before LC and had WG consensus on that change
zcorpan: given how long it took to get the title be something everyone in that discussion was happy with, i'd rather not reopen that discussion
MikeSmith: that doesn't mean we can't make any related changes, but we are unlikely to reconsider and make it an LC blocker
OK
Hixie: i'd be suprised if anyone objected to s/including/plus/ but ok
+1 to plus
makes sense to me too fwiw
(though the term HTML5 would still be used differently, but that seems fine)
I support s/including/plus/
"HTML5+"
lol
Philip`: for all those people who miss "HTML+"
whoah, HTML+ had a figure element! (named FIG, but still...)
html3 had a <math> element
a lot of the stuff in html5 is inspired by older drafts
much like a lot of the stuff in html "6" will be inspired by things we dropped in 5
like datagrid
HTML+ also had a LIT element for content to be rendered literally, but in a proportional font, giving a verse example
that's a neat idea
though of course you could just style PRE
nessy: can you remind me if any of the media subgroup proposals are ready for moving forward within the a11y TF this week?
I think they are both, actually
OK
you mean at Friday's meeting?
I will add them to the agenda
ah, ok - I thought that had already happened last week :)

"HTML+ documents offer a means for providing hypertext links to a variety of media including images, sound sequences, MPEG movies, Postscript files and other formats." - we still don't have MPEG support :-(
discussion will keep going though, but an in-principle agreement that we are on the right way and ready for trial implementations would be good
nessy: what's the state of the media subgroup proposals?
http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/HTML/wiki/Media_TextAssociations
http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/HTML/wiki/Media_MultitrackAPI
nessy: the chairs (well, me and Sam) were wondering today when to put out a formal Call for Proposals for ISSUE-9 video-accessibiity
oh!
well, the latter one is related ot issue-9
I guess I assumed that because the subgroup existed, the video a11y related issues and bugs were sorta "delegated"
I think after MikeSmith has had them discussed at the a11y TF meeting, it'd be good to introduce them to the larger html wg
nessy: everything ultimately has to go through the HTML WG process
sure
nessy: quick question about the first - how do <track> and <trackgroup> interact with <source>?
nessy: I think the movement forward on the proposals is pending me putting them to the a11y TF for sign-off that we are ready to formally ask for review from the wider WG
not at all
MikeSmith, agree - just what I thought
all the examples use <video src="">, and not multiple <source> elements
and it is not clear to me how you would use them with <source> elements
could you add examples like that?
that's just because after the source selection algorithm, a single video source will be dealt with
I'll add an example, no problems
do all <track> elements apply to all sources, regardless of which is picked?
yes
that seems problematic
they are external files that get associated to the selected video source
how so?
there's no guarantee <source>es are of equal length
e.g. based on device features you might get a shorter video
doesn't think that's especially problematic
I think that's an author's problem if he provides alternatives that are not really alternatives
I was thinking you might want the option to nest <track> inside <source>, but I am not sure there is a compelling use case
currently the primary use for <source> is different formats, but I expect that to shift over time
yeah, we had such a proposal at one stage
the example I thought of is, you have one video with no captions, one video with burned-in captions, and external captions in other languages
I am not sure if that is realistic
nessy, why would they not be alternatives?
such an example is realistic
alternatives is not a good word choice
zcorpan, yeah, maybe not
othermaciej, nesting inside <source> might no longer be feasible

but what I mean is: right now the choice is mostly based on formats, and maybe later on devices (through the media queries) - what is provided to the user should, however, not be a different experience
othermaciej, unless we change deployed content and fix our parsers quickly...
it would be strange if you went to a site on different browsers and you got different videos
annevk: we might need to make <source> imply </source> to do that
yuck
annevk: yes, nesting inside <source> was rejected because of that problem
othermaciej, still fails for the last though I suppose </video> could close the last one...
nessy: the basic idea of Media_TextAssociations seems pretty good
nessy: is that what the SRT vs DFXP vs smilText format war has been about?
it tried to really match with the way in which tracks are encoded in MPEG, too, including the track grouping
well, the srt - DFXP - smilText discussion is about what external format to support - the markup itself seems rather uncontroversial by now
also, it seems only the SMIL  guys are for smilText  nobody else has spoken up for it yet
really, requiring DFXP?
omg
several voices have been for DFXP - mostly those that want professional captioning
nessy: the track access API also seems reasonable - I worry slightly that it's more power than needed for the use case, but we may end up going that way anyway
DFXP is extremely broken
and way too complex
but we seem to be agreeing that DFXP needs to define conformance levels, which will make it easier to implement support for it
I think it would be plausible to not require any format or require only SRT (which I gather is the bare-bones format)
SRT has some weird stuff too
is smilText less broken than DFXP?
it would need to be defined
I'm not sure we'd want either
it seems to me that SRT addresses well over 80% of the use cases
for the rest we could provide an API so you can implement stuff yourself
we will need to have something more than DFXP since captioning requirements by law require more quality than what DFXP can provide, IIUC
(that's US law)
SRT addresses subtitles very well
quality captioning has actually more indepth requirements, such as colours and formatting and positioning
nothing that couldn't be done with a simple subpart of DFXP and a mapping to HTML+CSS
so DFXP is really complicated, but still cannot meet US legal requirements for captioning?
at the lowest level, DFXP could be no more than SRT plus basic formatting markup in the captions plus CSS
no, no, DFXP meets all US legal requirements
I referred to SRT not meeting them
I see, ok
sorry about the double negation :)
"we will need to have something more than DFXP" - did you mean SRT there?
I thought SRT had formatting extensions
I think all browser vendors will initially only want to implement srt - and that's fine
are the track roles defined in Media_MultitrackAPI all things that can be determined in common container formats?
(Otherwise I'm not quite understanding)
Philip`: i think she did
Philip`, I think so
I think we have to take it in steps
nessy: what legal requirements does the U.S. have that .srt doesn't meet?
Philip' good catch - I said DFXP where I meant SRT
nessy: is there any expected use for <track> besides external caption tracks?
I meant: we will need to have something more than SRT
(wondering if the name is too general)
considering what closed captioning in the U.S. looks like on e.g. CNN, it's hard for me to believe that SRT didn't meet legal requirements

hsivonen: I don't know the details but apparently you need to be able to place captions at locations where they don't overlap central activity, you need to be able to mark up in colour and provide italics for certain things and stuff

othermaciej: I'm hoping we can use the <track> spec also for lyrics, karaoke and other such text stuff, and ultimately also for other audio and video tracks, though that last one will take a long time before browsers will feel comfortable implementing it
it seems we need to define something like Web SRT anyway; adding extensions for a few things shouldn't be too hard and definitely much easier than DFXP

The <command> element is buggy in Firefox.  It is documented and validates only as self closing tag, but Firefox will not close the tag without a </COMMAND>.  So, you can pick your poison; you can not use the element all-together, you can markup the element as a self-closing tag and suffer the Firefoxequences, or you can add the closing tag and ignore validation all-together.
JonathanNeal, can't you put it in another tag, so when Firefox hits the wrapper's close tag, it will close it?
AryehGregor, <command /> will not close, so the next <command /> will be a child of the previous.
JonathanNeal: I expect he means
(or similar)
The next element will be a child of <command, until it is closed by some other means.

What does
do, or whatever? Does that make sense here?
isn't clear on how or why one would use <command> in practice, so isn't sure if that makes sense.
Why does it matter how Firefox parses it, given that the functionality is not implemented?
And right, does it matter how it gets parsed?
Say: <menu type="toolbar">
<command onclick="insertTag(buttons, 0);"  label="strong" icon="bold.gif"/>
<command onclick="insertTag(buttons, 1);"  label="em" icon="italic.gif"/>
</menu>
Ah crap, XChat didn't catch the line returns, sorry.
So why can't they just be nested in Firefox?
I mean, they're invisible anyway, aren't they?  Or are you styling them somehow?
<div> or <span> wrappers should fix it, anyway.
AryehGregor, nested as in each command being a child of the previous?
Yeah.
What's making these visible at all?
Well, then the styling would get in the way.
It seems a bad idea to use those elements at all, because the spec might change (given that there's no implementations yet, as far as I'm aware)
Yeah, I would very strongly advise that you avoid using anything with zero implementations.
That is a Catch 22.
No, it's not.
Implementations happen before features are used in authoring.
By the time there's implementations, the parsers will have been fixed
Once there's at least one implementation, you can test in that implementation.
It is the developers who have dictated the implementations.
That's how this whole mess started.
Huh?
If authors deploy features without implementations, then implementers may find that the sites break when the feature is actually implemented.
If your site is big enough, that will hold up their implementation.  If it's not, then your site will break.
In any event, you gain nothing by using features that don't exist yet in *any* browser, so what's the point?  Use <input type=image> instead.
AryehGregor, you're referring to Gecko or Webkit implementing <command> ?  Okay, I just wanted to use a recommended element as a child of <menu>
Why do you want to use <menu>?
Nobody implements that either :-)

Oh, duh.  role=presentation

Wait, so it's good but bad?
You want to use role=presentation. But it's officially disallowed right now in HTML5 (only can have it).
Oh, and I want presentational html.
Alternately...  Just use empty elements and/or images with no alt for the controls.  If the controls don't *contain* any content, they can't be read out.
